locations.description:
• The problem is clear, but you'll need to decide how to <c="green">solve it</c>.
• Chop down trees to build a raft, or swim across (might want to practice first), or build a bridge, or look for vines.
• Alternatively, you could play an <c="green">escape room</c>.

Shouldn't last indefinitely, as many scenarios could.
locations.name: River Crossing

locations.description: Attempt to take over the world, or at least a significant part of it. Could also be in outer space. Develop technology and build resources along the way. This could be simple like Risk, or complex like Civilization.
locations.name: Empire

locations.description: • Various forms of transportation for part of the trip: train, bus, taxi, plane, boat, wagon. • Buy food as well as tickets, with a limited supply of money. • Consider a foreign country, with some descriptions in other languages. Include English translations if you plan on sharing the scenario with a wider audience. • Keep your party safe and healthy through setbacks and challenges. • The goal could be reaching new territory to settle, winning a bet, or arriving at a vacation spot. Classic examples are the game Oregon Trail and the book Around the World in 80 Days by Jules Verne.
locations.name: Journey

locations.description: • Play at politics to get elected. Try an inspiring slogan to gain popularity, such as, Change for a brighter future! • Persuade congress to pass important laws that the people care about, such as, More Dogs and Fewer Cats. • Build a bigger city, with transportation, schools, hospitals, and fire departments. SimCity is a good example of city-building, though it doesn't go much into diplomacy.
locations.name: Mayor

locations.description: Construct locations and items to precisely and beautifully describe architecture. Describe both structure and function, for example an exquisite (or run-down) dining room along with people seated at the table with food. The people won't take actions, so they could be represented in the game as items rather than characters. Operate on a budget or have access to unlimited resources. This could be played cooperatively or competitively. Optionally, vote at the end to determine who wins.
locations.name: Building

locations.description: • For example, Underwater Abyss — legends speak of a nexus where all currents meet, with healing powers to save a loved one who is gravely ill. • Difficulties such as pressure, with features to explore such as sunken ships. • Or set in the desert, with tombs and traps. An RPG similar to the pre-built Dungeon Crawl scenario, except with less focus on fighting and more on tricky situations. The Choose Your Own Adventure books beautifully demonstrate this type of story.
locations.name: Adventure

overall.description: Look through this list and take inspiration from one of them, beginning with a blank setup.
overall.title: Unformed Ideas
